content:
Constraint says P can be as large as 10^16 but stub is reading P into an int.
Please fix.

Since P can be 0 < P < 10^16, it should rather be a "long" than an "int" in my opinion.

Caused an arithmetic error in my C++ solution.

Test/Validator 6 present a non-injective code that's not really in character. More prosaically: the "alphabet" there is NOT an alphabet: it has duplicates.

Just about all the pairs have a larger N in the validator than in the test, which is bad practice all around.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Was able to validate the solution using modulo and just looping through.  I think this is a good easy puzzle and like the changes that were made based on the replies.

I think the puzzle is ready for approval but the description is still a bit messy imo, so here's a reworked version as a proposal, let me know what you think of it.

You are an FBI agent and you intercepted a message from terrorists.
This message has to be decrypted, and in order to do that you have access to 2 pieces of information: P and C.

C is the alphabet used to write the message, and contains all the letters/characters needed to decode it.

P corresponds to the encoded value of the message.
Thankfully, you happen to know how this value is computed, and now need to reverse the following process :
 - Assuming the alphabet is 'abcd', each letter is associated to its index : a = 0, b = 1, c = 2, d = 3.
 - Then, a new letter is appended for the next values : aa = 4, ba = 5, ca = 6, da = 7, ab = 8, bb = 9, cb = 10, etc.
 - The whole message gets a unique value this way. For example with a full alphabet (26 letters) 'hello' would be 7073801.

Get it done agent !

I would not name this puzzle brute force, it doesn't anything to do with that technique.
It only requires a simple modulo management, which is fine for an easy puzzle, but brute force is something very different and usually related to backtracking.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this puzzle. Some comments:
- Test 6 : This uses a non-ascii character °. Using languages which encode strings as utf8, this has to be handled. E.g. in Rust "°".len() != "°".chars().count(). And Validator 6 does not reflect this, containing no special char. But better than the other way round ;).
- Maybe you want to rename the variable "A" in your code stub also to "C"
- "INPUT" : Caractères => characters, or maybe better "coding alphabet" ?
- "OUTPUT" combinaison => combinations. Maybe "the pth combination of characters of the coding alphabet".
- "Constraints" : "Do a BrutForce modulable" Not sure what this means? Maybe "Use brute force"?

"you will have 2 pieces of information: P and A."
"You will also have a second info C"

What happened to A?
Sorry I can't understand the statement :(

I like your puzzle, however i think i have a solution with no brute force.
I just use modulo to get the final result.
you maybe set the puzzle to easy, it also could be a clash of code.
i think the goal is not clear enough: you need to precise how to find the list of combinations

But saying that you need to Brute Force may be a trick :)

I could send you my algorythm if you want.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I guess the ideal difficulty would be somewhere between "easy" (if you already know the trick) and "medium" (if not), but since that's not an option, either end of the spectrum seems fine to me.
It's a fun puzzle, but I don't think you have the difficulty set correctly (it's practically a one-liner with Ruby and its #digits method).

Thanks for doing my puzlle and ok, I gonna to change the difficulty level... 
To the "off-by-one errors", I'll see what I can do.

You must to do a Brut Force : It's a code who test ALL possibility of "code".
For example, (All possibilities with 1234) are :
1
2
3
4
11
21
31
41
12
22
...
After, you know the position of the good password... For instance, if the good position is 6 (with 1234), you must to return 31 because :
1 -> Position 0
2 -> Position 1
3 -> P 2
4 -> P 3
11 -> P 4
21 -> P 5
31 -> P 6
ATTENTION : The caractère 1234 change to each example...
I hope that explains a little better...
Thank’s to your comment. I have done a mistake (A and C are same). I going to correct :->

Thank's to your comment and your approving.
Now, I have corrected 'my mistakes'...
thanks again, BiMathAx

Hello, thank's to your comment, you said that we can solve my contribution using modulo but I hade tried and I don't see how to do this...
Can you explain at me (in MP or in tchat) pl ?
Thank's again, BiMathAx

Thank's much to your "new announcement" which explain easier than the old (So, I have proofread its).
Thank's again, BiMathAx
Thank's to your comment

I've taken the liberty of rewriting all the tests so they are much more consistent.
Although I'm not sure if it raises the difficulty of the puzzle now, the last tests won't let people use a suboptimal solution.

BiMathAx I hope you don't mind. I'm not trying to hijack your puzzle, just making it more consistent :D

Making it more consistent: +1
Making the new Ps go *way* over the advertised constraint to the point of changing the complexity class: -1 (especially after it's published)

Whoops forgot about that, I updated the constraint.
The previous value of P was to limiting imo, especially to get some results like hello world, but idk maybe that was to ambitious.

Edit : for the released part, it's clear that the puzzle was released to early (unlike what I thought, live and learn). It's better to change it in depth now than to leave it in a bad state.
So now people are out there with an accepted solution that doesn't work anymore. Bad.

Oh come on, the puzzle has been out for 24h and has been solved by 35 people.
Can you be even more negative plz ?

I could if I wanted to :p

More seriously, making the puzzle better is good; changing the class of solutions that qualify isn't.

I've made a few changes to the puzzle description and also changed the title, 'find good message' wasn't really proper english.
Also I modified test 6 to get rid of the ascii problem, I don't think there was a reason to keep that.
ok thank's
I've sent you a PM on the forum.

Disregard the bit about off-by-one errors; the problem was in my understanding of how a certain method yielded digits, not in your test cases. Sorry about that.

Will definitely approve this as a medium-difficulty puzzle.
OK thanks a lot
